—A—

A - ΦI (or AΡ - ΦI) MID I BC

Grunauer, p. 53 (emission mark 6 ), Gruppe XIII (48-40 BC), Serie 5, Tafel 8, Gruppe XIV (48-40 BC), Serie 11, Tafel 8, Gruppe XV (48-40 BC), Serie 9-10, Tafel 9, Gruppe XVI (43-31 BC), Serie 1, Tafel 11 suggests Amphimachos or Amphis (but the abbreviation seems to include a rho)

Κλαύδιος Ἀγαθεῖνος MID-END I AD

Galen (ed. C. G. Kühn, Leipzig, 1821-33) de febrium differentiis II 9 (VII 367), de pulsum differentia IV 10-11 (VIII 748-54), de dignoscendis pulsibus I 3 (VIII 787), IV 2 (VIII 935-37), de venae sectione adversus Erasistratum 5 (XI 163), de compositione medicamentorum per genera V 11 (XIII 830), Hippocratis Epidemion I et Galeni in illum commentarius II 25 (XVII 1, 120), Hippocratis Epidemion VI et Galeni in illum commentarius II 26 (XVII 1, 942-43), definitiones medicae 14 (XIX 353); vita A. Persi Flacci; Caelius Aurelianus de morbis acutis III 16 169; IG XIV 2064; Prosopographia Imperii Romani1 Saec. I II III, ed. Edmund Groag and Arthur Stein, Berlin, 1932-, 772 Claudius Agathinus

A Lacedaemonian (def. med. 14) physician, student of L. Annaeus Cornutus and Athenaeus. Founder of a school of medicine and author of several treatises.

Ἀγάθων ROMAN PERIOD

IG V 1. 772

Gravemarker: thirty-two years old at death

Ἀγαμέ[ν]η[ς] END III BC

IG II2 835 (Helen Pope, Foreigners in Attic Inscriptions, Philadelphia, 1947, “Lacedaemonii”)

Son of Apolla—

Brother of Tharrhynon

His father (and himself as his father’s descendant) was granted the rights of proxenia by the Athenians in a year soon after 229/8 BC.

[Gerousias]

Ἀγασικλῆς 590-560 BC

Poralla 2 (appendix Eurypontiden)a; Pausanias III 7.6-7b; Herodotus I 65c

Son of Hippokratidasa

Brother of Agesilaosa

[Son of Archidamos]b

Father of Aristonb

Eurypontid king

Agasikles, as a contemporary of Leon, is supposed to have led the abortive war against Tegea,c but Pausanias states that he undertook no war.

Ἀγασίων ROMAN PERIOD

IG V 1. 785

Gravemarker: forty-four years old at death

Ἀγασισθένης MID II BC

Pausanias VII 12.7

Author of a motion in the gerousia, ca. 150 BC, that twenty-four citizens go into voluntary exile to avoid furnishing the Achaean League with a pretext for war.

Ἀγγενίδας LATE V BC

Poralla 3; Xenophon Hellenica II 3.10

Eponymous ephor of the year 426/5

Ἀγέλοχος EARLY V BC

Poralla 4 (Stemma, cf. Tisamenos); Herodotus IX 33; Pausanias III 11.5-8

Son of Tisamenos

Father of Hagias

Descended from the Elean family of the Iamids, but his father had received full citizenship in Sparta shortly before 480 BC

AΓH 219-196 BC

Grunauer, Gruppe VIII, Serie 9 (), Tafel 5 (36-37)

Name on a coin—perhaps the mint official but more likely the holder of the eponymous office, at this date probably the eponymous patronomos

AΓH

Τι(βέριος) Κλαύδιος Ἀγήμων (2) I\II AD

Rizakis #254; IG V 1. [58]a, 667b; SEG XI 563c

Agonothetes of the Greater Uranian Augustan Nervian games in the year of Menekles (5), AD 96/7b; [gerousias]c; pres[bys] of [ephors?]a in the year of [Agesi]las, ca. 97/8 or [Prato]las ca. 115-120

Ἀγήμων (3) IG V 1. 195

IG V 1. 195

Father of Anonymus (Fragment 5)

Ἀγήνωρ II\I BC

Papyrus grecs et démotiques, ed. Théodore Reinach, Paris, 1905, 15, I 29;

16, II 36-37; 20, I 35; 23, I 27

Son of Barkaios

Lacedaemonian mercenary in Egypt, 109-105 BC

Ἀγήξενος II BC

IG V 1. 965

Father of Aristagoras (1), a Lacedaemonian

Ἀγησανδρίδας LATE V BC

Poralla 5; Thucydides VIII 91.2, 94-5a, 107b; Diodorus XIII 41c; Xenophon Hellenica I 1.1d, 3.17e

Son of Agesandros

Brother of Pasitelidas

In 411 he defeated the Athenian fleet near Oropus and caused Euboea to defect.a

After the battle of Cynossema he went to the Hellespont under the orders of the nauarch Min­dares, but was shipwrecked near Athos.bc With the ships that were saved he defeated the Athenian Thymochares.d

In 409/8 he was in Thrace.e

Ἀγήσανδρος MID V BC

Poralla 6; Thucydides I 139a, IV 132b, VIII 91c

{= Hegesandros, father of Pasitelidas?}b

Father of Agesandridasc

In 431 BC, as part of the third Spartan embassy, he presented the ultimatum to Athens before the outbreak of the Peloponnesian War.

Ἀγησίδας LATER VII BC

Poralla 7; Heraclides Ponticus 2.2 (Müller, Fragmenta

Historicorum Graecorum, Paris, 1878, II, p. 210)

Master of the poet Alcman

Ἀγησικλείδας REIGN OF DOMITIAN

SEG XI 513

Son of Damokrates (23)

Ephor in the year of Aristodamos (8), ca. 87/8 or earlier

Ἀγησίλαος I X\IX BC

Poralla 8 (cf. Appendix Agiden); Herodotus VII 204; Pausanias III 2.4

Son of Doryssos

Father of Archelaos

Agid king

According to the ancient chronographers he ruled for 44 years, but

Pausanias assigns him only a short reign.

Ἀγησίλαος II 444/3-360/59 BC

Poralla 9; Diodorus 14.80a, 15.31-34b, 82.6-83.5c, 92-3d; Nepos Agesilaus (8e), Timotheus 1.3f, Conon 2, Chabrias 1,2, de regibus 1; Pausanias III 8.8ffg, 9.1-5h, IV 17.5, VI 4.9, 15.7, VIII 6.2, IX 13.2, 14.5; Plutarch Agesilaus (1i, 3j, 6k, 7-13l, 17-19m, 20n, 21o, 22p, 27-8q, 31-33r, 34s, 36-40t), Lysander 22u, 24v, Lycurgus 30.5, Artaxerxes 22.4-7, Moralia (de audiendis poetis) 31c, (de adulatore et amico) 52f, 55d, (de profectibus in virtute) 78d, 81a, 85b, (regum et imperatorum apophthegmata) 189e, (apophthegmata Laconica) 208b-215a, 229f, (parallela Graeca et Romana) 308b, (de Alexandri fortuna) 343a, (de Pythiae oraculis) 399b, (de fraterno amore) 482d, (de vitioso pudore) 533e-534b, (de laude ipsius) 545a, (de genio Socratis) 577e, 578f, (quaestionum convivalium II 10.2) 644b, (an seni sit gerenda res puiblica) 784ef, 790b, (praecepta gerendae reipublicae) 805e, 807e, 809a/b, (non posse suaviter vivi secundum Epicurum) 1099b; Hellenica Oxyrhyncus 11.2-5, 12.1-4, 13.1, 21.1-4, 22.2,4w; Xenophon Agesilaus (1.25-35x; 2.17y, 21z, 26-7A, 9.6B); HellenicaC III 3-4 passim; IV-VI passim, VII 5.9, 10; Aristotle Politica 1306b35; SEG XI 457 (father?); Libanius declamationes XXIV 2 (mel): 6; Isocrates epistulae IX 11-14, orationes IV 144, 153, V 62, 86, 87; Athenaeus IV 144b, IX 384a, XII 511c, 550e, XIII 609b, XIV 613c, 616d, 657b; Josephus Bellum Judaicum II 359; Diogenes Laertius II 51, 52, 57, VI 39, VIII 87; Die In­schrif­ten von Ephesos (der Österreichischen Akademie der Wissen­schaften) II 133

Eurypontid king

Son of King Archidamos II and Eupolia

Half-brother of King Agis II and Teleutias

Brother of KyniskainoB

Agesilaos was born in 444/3 and about 402 married Kleora (cf. Aristomenidas) who bore him three children, Archidamos, Eupolia, and Prolyta.mC

When, after the death of Agis II in the summer of 399, Agis’ son Leotychidas was disqualified, Agesilaos—particularly through the influence of his boyhood friend Lysander—received the throne.Cujg

Likewise, through the efforts of Lysander was Agesilaos appointed the commander in the war against Persia. He sailed in the spring of 396 from Aulis to Ephesus.kCh

He conducted the war in Asia Minor until the summer of 394, when he was recalled because of political developments in Greece.Cxwlva

In thirty days he marched to Boeotia, where he established a camp at Chaeroneia on the 25th or 26th of August 394 and soon thereafter defeated the enemies of Sparta in the battle of Coronea.Cm

To heal the wound that he had received in the battle he took himself to Delphi and from there travelled home on a ship.Cx

In 391 he laid waste to Argos and continued on to Corinth where he had the long walls of Lechaeum torn down.Cy

In the summer of the next year <390> he was active at the IsthmusCop. There he fought on behalf of the Achaeans against the Acarnanians.Cp

At the peace conference in Sparta in 387/6 he forced through the recognition of the King’s Peace on the part of the Thebans and the dissolution of the just founded city Corinth-Argos.Cz

In the fall of 381 he struck against Phlius, which he took after a siege of twenty months.C

In similar fashion he participated in the great struggle between Thebes and Sparta. He undertook two operations to Boeotia in 378/7. A wound, which he received on the march back, kept him from the theater of war for a long time,Cb so he acted all the more energetically against Thebes in 371 at the congress at Sparta, when he excluded the Thebans from the common peace.Cq

After the catastrophe at Leuctra he campaigned with the full army against Mantinea, but had to withdraw to Sparta at the approach of the Thebans.C By his careful handling he saved the country from the invasion of Epaminondas in the winter of 370/69.r

Around 364 he travelled to Asia to earn money for Sparta and fought there together with the Athenian Timotheos for the interests of Ariobarzanes.Af

In 362 we find the king back in Greece, where shortly before the battle of Mantinea he saved Sparta a second time from a Theban invasion.Csc

In 361 he went to Egypt to enter the service of Tachos, to earn money for Sparta as the leader of a mercenary band. When he was demoted by Tachos he went over to Nectanebo and did important service for him. Therefore, when he prepared his return home, he was loaded with rich gifts. He never reached his homeland, but died in the winter of 360/59 between Egypt and Cyrene in the “harbor of Menelaos.” His body was brought back to Sparta.tde

Ἀγησίλαος VI BC

Poralla 10 (cf. Appendix Eurypontiden); Herodotus VI 65 (“Agis”),

VIII 131

Son of Hippokratidas

Father of Menares

Grandfather of King Leotychidas II

Collateral relative of the house of the Eurypontids

Ἀγησίλαος MID IV BC

Poralla 11 (cf. Appendix Eurypontiden); Arrian Anabasis 2.13.6; Plutarch

Agis 3

Member of the Eurypontid royal house

Son of Archidamos III

Brother of Agis III and Eudamidas I

He was sent to Crete by Agis III in 333 with a troop of mercenary soldiers.

Ἀγησίλαος IV BC

Poralla 12; IG V 1. 3

His son, as the agent for Sparta, concluded an alliance.

Ἀγησίλαος LATE VI BC

Poralla 12a; [Plutarch] Moralia (Parallela minora 10) 308b

Here erroneously as the father of Pausanias (the victor of Plataea) when the name should have been Kleombrotos (cf. Alkathoa note)

IG V 1. 79

Ἀγησίλαος (2) EARLY-MID III BC

Plutarch Agis 6.3-7.2a, 9.1b, 12.4-13.5c, 16.1-5d, 18.5e, 19.6f; comparatio Agis Cleomenes Ti. Gracchus C. Gracchus 4.1g; Polybius IV 35.13h; IG XII 8. 156i; Prometheus VII 1981, pp. 35-42: Agis became king as a child and Agesilaos was his regent.

Son of Eudamidas [(1) I]h

Father of Hippomedon (1)adhi

Uncle and supporter of Agis IVabef. He escaped debt through the reforms of Agisac, became ephorcd, refused to relinquish the officed, and avoided execution only through the intervention of his son.d He went into exile in 241 BC.d

Ἀγησίπολις V BC

Poralla 13; IG V 1. 1338 ([hι]αρὸς hΑγηhίπολις)

Priest (in Laconian Gerenia?)

Ἀγησίπολις I V\IV BC

Poralla 14; Diodorus XIV 89a, XV 22,2, 23,2b; Pausanias III 5.7c, VIII 8.7-9(f); Xenophon Hellenica IV 2.9d, 7.2-7e; V 2.3-7f, 3.8-9, 18-9g (Agesipolis and Agesilaus have been confused in Suidas s. v. Ἆγις and Diodorus XIV 97.5.)

Agid king

Son of King Pausanias

Brother of Kleombrotos

When his father went into exile after the battle of Haliartos in 395, Agesipolis ascended the throneac. Since he was still a minor, he had a regent, Aristodemusd.

In 388/7 he led a successful campaign against the Argivese. In 385/4 he forced Mantinea to disband the league it had formedf. In the year 381 he invaded Chalcidice with a great army, but died shortly after the capture of Torone in Summer 380.

His body was brought to Spartabg.

Ἀγησίπολις II EARLY IV BC

Poralla 15; Plutarch Agis 3a, Diodorus XV 60.4b; Pausanias I 13.4, III 6.2c

Son of Kleombrotosa

Brother of Kleomenes IIa

Agid kinga

After the death of his father in 371 Agesipolis succeeded to the throne,

but he died after about a one-year reign and left no childrenabc.

Ἀγησίπολις (1) MID-END III BC

Polybius IV 35.10-12; [Plutarch Agis 18.3]

Son of Kleombrotos (1) II and Chilonis (2)

Brother of Kleomenes (2)

Father of Agesipolis (2) III

He was young enough in 241 BC to be carried by a parent. He died

before 219 BC.

Ἀγησίπολις (2) III III\II BC

Polybius IV 35.10-12a; XXIII 6.1-2b; Livy XXXIV 26.14c

Son of Agesipolis (1)a

Grandson of Kleombrotos (1) IIa

Agiad king

He was appointed king as a child after the death of Kleomenes (1) III,

219 BCab His uncle, Kleomenes (2), was regenta. He was expelled

by Lykourgos (1)c. As an envoy to Rome, ca. 184 BC, he was

killed by piratesb.

Ἀγησιππία (1) MID II AD

IG V 1. 502

Daughter of Onasion (2)

Mother of Kleon (9)

Wife of Kleon (8)

She paid for a memorial to her son.

[hA]γηḣιππία (2)

SEG XI 677

Daughter of Hipparchos (5)

For eight years amphithaleus of Demeter and Kore

Ἀγησιππίδας END V BC

Poralla 16; Thucydides V 52 (Ἡγησιππίδας), 56

Commandant in Heraclea. In the summer of 419 he was sent back to

Sparta by the Boeotians, because he had mismanaged his post.

In the following winter he led reinforcements to the aid of the

Epidaurians who were hard pressed by the Argives.

Ἀγησιστράτα DIED 241 BC

Plutarch Agis 4.1-2a, [6.5b, 7.2c], 18.8d, 20.2-7e

Daughter of Eudamidas {(1) I} and Archidamiae

Sister of Agesilaos (2) {and Archidamos <2> IV}b

Wife of Eudamidas (2) II, q. v.

Mother of Agis (1) IVa and Archidamos (3) {V}

She and her mother were the wealthiest persons in Spartaa. They

contributed their wealth and influence to the reforms of Agis IVc

and were executed with him in 241 BCe

Ἀγήτα (3 = 4?) I BC

(or [Θ]ΕΟΔΩΡΟΣΞΑΓΗΤΑΣ means that [Th]eodoros was an {e}xagetas)

Ἀγήτα (5)

Mother of Harmoneikos the Heraclid

Wife of Ariston a Messenian

A Lacedaemonian by descent from her “fathers” (who include Heracles and the Dioscuri)

Ἀγητορίδας (1) FIRST HALF IV BC

Poralla 19; Plutarch Moralia (de genio Socratis 7) 578e

A Spartiate who was sent by Agesilaos II to Memphis during the time when Plato was travelling in Egypt. We do not have an exact date for Plato’s Egyptian stay. Plato left Athens after the death of Socrates and travelled through the Peloponnesus, to Egypt and Cyrene. In 388 he had already visited Syracuse again. The trip of Agetoridas then, if it is at all historical, must fall in the period 399-388.

IG V 1. 177 (cf. SEG XI 634)

Son of Damokratidas (10)

Name in a catalogue

Ἁγίας VI\V BC

Poralla 21; Herodotus IX 33 (the name is known in the Ionian form:

Ἡγίης)

Son of the Elean Antiochos

Brother of the famous Elean seer Tisamenos.

Along with his brother he received Spartan citizenship shortly before the

battle of Marathon.

Ἁγίας END V BC

Poralla 22; Pausanias III 11. 5-6, X 9.7 (where his name is written Ἄβας)

Son of Agelochos

He belonged to the Elean family of seers which had been given citizenship in Sparta around 480. He took part in the battle of Aegospotami. (cf. Τισαμενός stemma)

Ἁγίας MID IV BC

Poralla 23; FDelph III5. 19, 65

Prostates of the naopoioi in the year of the Delphian archon Theucharis, Spring 354

Ἁ[γία]ς I BC

IG V 1. 210

Son of Leuktri—

Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Kallikrates (33)

Ἀγιᾶτις DIED ca. 224 BC

Plutarch Cleomenes 1.1-3, 22.1-3, [Aratus 39.3]

Daughter of Gylippos (1)

Wife of Agis (1) IV and mother of a son by him

Wife of Kleomenes (1) III and mother of at least two sons by him

(Cleom. 38.3)

She was a wealthy woman. After the death of Agis IV, Leonidas (1) II forced her to marry his son, Kleomenes, so that her wealth would not pass to another. She was supposed to have encouraged Kleomenes in his reforms.

Ἀγιδώ LATER VII BC

Poralla 24; D. L. Page, Alcman, the Partheneion, Oxford. 1951)

Ἆγις I HEROIC AGE

Poralla 25; Herodotus I 65a, VII 204b; Strabo VIII 365c; Pausanias III 16.9d

Son of Eurysthenesab

Father of Echestratos and, according to one version, of the lawgiver Lycurgusab.

He was the eponymous king of the house of the Agids—obviously a mythical personab.

During his reign (1061-1030/29) the helots were subjugatedc. He is also made the ultimate ancestor of the mythical Amphiklesd.

Ἆγις II DIED 399 BC

Poralla 26; Thucydides III 89a, IV 2. 6b, V 19, 24c, 54d, 57-60 & 63-75e, 83f, VII 19 & 27g, VIII 3h, 5-11 & 70-71i; Plutarch Agesilaus 1. 3j; Diodorus XI 48k, XII 35.4l, 78-79m, XIII 107n; Xenophon Hellenica I 1.33-35o, II 2. 7-13p, II 3.3q, III 2.22-29 & 3.1r; Pausanias III 8.3-5s, VI 2.3t; IDelos 87 (IG V 1. 1564); Justin V 2.5; Nepos Agesilaus 1; Athenaeus XII 535b, 543b

King from the house of the Eurypontids

Son of Archidamos II

Step brother of Agesilaos II

Father of Leotychidas (by Timaia)j.

After the death of Archidamos Agis assumed the throne in 427/6k. In the years 426 and 425 he twice led the army into Attica.ab With his fellow king Pleistoanax in 421 he underwrote the peace of Nicias and the alliance with Athens.c

In 419 he marched with the assembled army to Leuctra, but turned back to Sparta without accomplishing anything.d In the next summer he campaigned twice against the Argives and besieged them because of their alliance with Mantineaem. In a third campaign at the beginning of the winter of 417 he caused the newly built walls of Argos to be torn downf.

In spring 413 Agis invaded Attica and seized Decelea, where he remained as commanderg. From here he undertook in the following winter a campaign against the Oitaians and the Achaeans living in Phthiotis, to reestablish the influence of the Spartans on the Malean Gulfh. From Decelea Agis supported all rebellions against Athens in Asia Minor and along the Hellespont and tried several times to take the cityio. He did not take part in the siege of Athens in 405/4nq, although he did offer his good ofices to the Atheniansp.

After the fall of Athens he led a long campaign against Elist and visited Delphi. On his return trip he fell sick and died soon after his arrival in Sparta, probably in the summer of 399lrs.

Ἆγις III DIED 330 BC

Poralla 27; Plutarch Agis 3a; Pausanias III 10.5b; Arrian Anabasis II 13.6c; Diodorus XVI 88.4d, XVII 48.1-2e, 62.6-63.4f; Curtius VI 1g

Eurypontid king

Son of Archidamos III

Brother of Eudamidas and Agesilaosabc

He succeeded his father in 338 and ruled for nine yearsd. In 333, as leader of the opposition to Alexander the Great, Agis travelled to Siphnos to meet Pharnabazos and Autophradates, the commanders of the Persian fleet; he obtained money and troops from them. Then he travelled to Halicarnassos where he led some of the survivors of the Greek mer­cenaries from the battle of Issos to Cretece. After he returned to Sparta he besieged Megalopolis, but in a battle fought there against Antipater, he was killed (in 331 or 330)fg.

Agis left no descendantsa.

Ἆγις MID IV BC

Poralla 28; Nikandros Anthologia Palatina VII 435

Son of Iphikratidas and Alexippa

He and his brothers (Eupylidas, Chairis, Lykos, Alexon, Eraton, and Gylippos) fell at Messene sometime after 369.

Ἆγις, Poralla 28a; Herodotus VI 65, cf. Ἀγησίλαος (Poralla 10)
Ἆγις, Poralla 28b; Suidas s. v., cf. Ἀγησίπολις I
Ἆγις ( = III?) END IV BC

SEG I 87 (dated by letter forms)

Dedication [for a victory] to Apollo

Ἆγις (1) IV DIED 241 BC

Plutarch Agis passim, Cleomenes 1-3, Agesilaus 40.5; comparatio Agis Cleo­menes Ti. Gracchus C. Gracchus, Aratus 31.1; Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica) 216d; Lamprias catalogue Number 9; Cicero de officiis II 80; Pausanias II 8.5; III 10.5; VI 2.4; VII 7.3; VIII 8.11, 10.5-8, 27.13-14, 36.6 (Pausanias confuses Agis IV and Archidamos IV); Prometheus VII 1981, pp. 35-42: Agis became king as a child with Agesilaos as his regent.

Son of Eudamidas (2) II and Agesistrata

Father of [Eurydamidas (Pausanias III 10.5)]

Husband of Agiatis

Eurypontid king of Sparta

He was the first king of Sparta to attempt to recover her military strength through an increase in the number of citizen-soldiers by cancellation of debt, distribution of land, and enfranchisement.

He was opposed by the wealthy and by Leonidas (1) II, the Agiad king, though a large minority of the fully enfranchised citizen body supported Agis.

With the help of his advisers and supporters, Lysandros (1), Mandrokleidas, and Agesilaos (2), he expelled Leonidas, brought Kleombrotos (1) II to the throne, and passed a bill cancelling debt.

He led an army to aid the Achaean League against the Aetolians, but no engagement was fought. In his absence his opponents gained the upper hand. (Pausanias confuses the actions of the Aetolians and the Spartans under Agis in his reading of Plutarch’s life of Aratus.)

Leonidas II returned from exile and forced Agis to seek sanctuary. Agis was betrayed, tried by the ephors, and executed.

Γά(ιος) Πομπώνιος Ἆγις (2) MID II AD

Rizakis 640 (Stemmata 1, 11); IG V 1. 71 (ΠΟ)a, 86 (ΓΑ ΠΩΝΠΟΝΙΟΣ)b, 494 (ΓΑ ΠΟΜΠΩ)c

Son of Alkastos (4)c

First cousin of C. Pompo(nius) Alkastos (3)c

Euporos (2) was kasen to hima

Subject of an honorary decree for his exercise of the office of gymnasiarchc; nomophy(lax)b; agonothetes and gra(mmato)phy(lax) of the Caesarian and Eurycleian games in the year of Agetoridas (3)b, AD 165/6 or later

Ἀγλαός I AD

Ἁγνή IG V 1. 733

Mother of Faustus, two more sons, and a daughter

She survived Faustus, who died in his forties

ΑΓΡΙ or ΑΠΡ 219-196 BC

Grunauer, Gruppe VIII, Serie 18 (), Tafel 5 (102)

Name on a coin—perhaps the mint official but more likely the holder of

the eponymous office, at this date probably the eponymous patronomos

[Ἀγρ]ίππας, IG V 1. 175, error for ἀλείπτας, cf. SEG XI 633
Ἀγύλαιος MID III BC

Plutarch Cleomenes 8.3-4 (Mss GP— Ἀγύλλαιος)

Ephor who survived an attack of the supporters of Kleomenes (1) III by simulating death and taking sanctuary in the temple of Phobos

Ἀγχίβιος “EARLY”

Poralla 29; IG V 1. 1134

Name on an inscription found in Geronthrai

Ἀγχιθέα, Poralla 29a; Suidas s. v. Παυσανίας, cf. Ἀλκαθόα
Ἀγχίμολος END VI BC

Poralla 30; Herodotus V 63 (Ἀγχιμόλιος); Aristotle Athenaion Politeia 19, Scholia to Aristophanes Lysistrata 1153

Son of Aster

Campaigned by ship against the Peisistratids in Athens in 511/10 and was defeated and killed by Hippias and the Thessalian cavalry. His grave memorial was located in the Attic deme Alopeke.

Ἀδαῖος, Poralla 30a; Plutarch Agesilaus 13, cf. Ἰδαῖος
Ἀδεξάκω[ν], see Ἀ{λ}εξάκω[ν]
Ἀδείμαντος EPHOR 220 BC

Polybius IV 22.7-23.9; J. Toepffer, “Adeimantos (7),” RE, I Halbband (Stuttgart, 1893), 355

Ephor who favored Philip V and who was murdered by the pro-Aetolian faction

Ἄδμητος (1) REIGN OF TRAJAN

SEG XI 626

Son of (Admetos [2])

Synarch of the gynaikonomia in the year of Nikokrates (12), AD 86/7 or

earlier

(Ἄδμητος [2]) I AD

SEG XI 626

Father of Admetos (1)

Ἀείμνηστος VI\V BC

Poralla 31; Plutarch Aristides 19 (Ἀρίμνηστος); Herodotus IX 64, Aristodemus II 5 in Müller, Fragmenta Historicorum Graecorum, Paris, 1878, V 5; Pausanias I 27.1 (not named, cf. Poralla 790)

A Spartiate who killed Mardonius in the battle of Plataea 479. He fell at Stenykleros in the third Messenian War.

Ἀθήναιος MID V BC

Poralla 32; Thucydides IV 119, 122

Son of Perikleidas

In Spring 423, as representative from Sparta with full powers he made

an armistice with Athens and traveled to Chalcidike to inform Brasidas

Ἀθήναιος, IG V 1. 164, see Φ[ι]λαθήναιος

Ἀθύμβραδος VIII BC

Poralla 35; Strabo XIV 650; (Etymologicum Magnum <T. Gaisford, Oxford 1848> s. v. [Akara—he is Cretan)

Brother of Athymbros and Hydreios, the mythical founders of Athymbrada in Asia Minor

Ἄθυμβρος? VIII BC

Poralla 36; Strabo XIV 650; (Etymologicum Magnum <T. Gaisford, Oxford 1848> s.v. [Akara—Athymbrados is Cretan)

Brother of Athymbrados and Hydreios, the mythical founders of three places in Caria which through a synoecismos established Nysa

Αἰγεύς III-II BC

Herodotus IV 149; Pausanias III 15.8

Son of Oiolykos the son of Theras

Aigeus is the eponym of the “great tribe in Sparta” (Hdt.), the Aegeidai.

see Euryleon

Αἰνησιμβρότα LATER VII BC

Poralla 41; Bergk Poetae Lyrici Graeci III p 43 v. 73ff

Young woman’s name in a chorus by Alcman. Four of the singers lived with her.

Αἰνητίδας I BC

IG V 1. 208

Father of Antilas (1)

Αἴνητος END V BC

Poralla 42; IG V 1. 701

A Laconian, who fell in war; an inscription of about the year 400 found

in Magula near Sparta

Αἴνητος

Poralla 43; Pausanias III 18.7

From Amyclae

He was a victor at Olympia in the pentathlon and died shortly after the victory. He had a portrait statue in Amyclae

Αἱρήσ[ιππος] V BC

Poralla 44; IG V 1. 702 (̇hΑΙΡΗh—)

He found his death in the field.

Αἱρήσιππος MID III BC

Poralla 45; Athenaeus VI 251f = FGrH 86 #13

Agatharchides of Cnidus mentioned him in the 30th book of his Europiaka. Book 27 has events of 244/3 BC. Book 31 has events of ca. 217 BC. Hairesippos, then, falls between these years.

Son of Aischro[n]

Ἄκανθος MID VIII BC

Poralla 46; Olymp 17; Africanus in Eusebius (Schoene) I 196. Philostratus Gymnastikos (Jüthner 12); Pausanias V 8.6; Dionysius Halicarnassus VII 72 (Cf. Eustathius Comm ad Iliadem Y 683, Pausanias I 44.1

A Spartiate who won the long distance run at Olympia, Ol. 15 = 720

Ἄκανθος MID V BC

Poralla 47; Thucydides V 19, 24

As a member of the college of ephors he concluded the peace of Nikias

and the alliance with Athens in spring 421.

Ἀκίνδοινος ROMAN PERIOD

IG V 1. 803

Gravemarker: nine years old at death

Λούκιος Ἀπρών[ιος] Ἀκίνδυνος MID II AD

Rizakis 35; IG V 1. 55a, [119?]b

[Gerousias?]b

Presbys of ephors in the year of C. Ju(lius) Lysikrates (1)a, AD 152/3

(Woodward, ABSA 26, 196 suggests he may have been the son of L. Apronius Praximenes and father/ancestor of L. Apronius Euelpistos.)

Ἀκματίδας Λακεδαιμόνιος MID VI BC

SEG XI 1227, XIV 355, XXIX 408; Hanson LGVI no 387 (hexameter plus three words), C. Gallavotti Metri 34; Moretti IAG 8; Olymp 160 (500 BC?)

Ἁκουσίων EARLY

Poralla 48; IG V 1. 217

Laconian inscription of very early time

Ἀκρατίδας MID IV BC

Poralla 49; FDelph III5 [48I20], [57B15], 58,26, [61B34], [92A23]

Naopoios in Delphi under the archon Demochares 338/7 and Kaphis

331/30 and spring 327 BC

Ἀκρότατος (1) MID IV BC

Diodorus Siculus XIX 70.4-71.6a, [XX 29.1]; Pausanias I 13.5, III 6.2, {VIII 27.11-13, VIII 30.7 by name refers to Akrotatos (1) but in fact refers to Akrotatos (2)}; Plutarch Agis 3.6b, Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica) 216de, 240ef (grandson of Gyrtias); SEG XI 668(?); SEG XXV 444; IOlymp, Number 308; ICret II xxiii 12A; {SIG3 430, see Akrotatos (2)}

First son of Kleomenes II

Brother of Kleonymos (1)

Father of Areus (1) Ib

He opposed the decree to relieve the survivors of the battle of Megalopolis, 331 BC, of ignominya.

He commanded the forces of Acragas in Sicily, ca. 314, against Agathokles, but he was stripped of his command and forced to return to Spartaa.

He predeceased his father (who died in 309 BC).b

Ἀκρότατος (2) MID III BC

Athenaeus IV 142b; Parthenius 23; Plutarch Agis 3.7a, Pyrrhus 26.18b, 28.4-7c, Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica) 240ef}; Pausanias III 6.6; {VIII 27.11-13, VIII 30.7 by name refers to Akrotatos (1) but in fact refers to Akrotatos (2)}; SIG3 430d (The editor assigns this inscription to Areus <1> and Akrotatos <1>, but the reference to “King” Akrotatos and “Queen” Chilonis seems to me rather to refer to this Akrotatos.)

Son of Areus (1) Ia

Husband of Chilonis (1)

Father of Areus (2) IId

Agiad kinga

Supposedly he committed adultery with the wife of his great uncle, Kleonymos (1), shaming him into leaving Spartab, a story which overlies the intense and bitter rivalry between the families of Areus I and Kleonymos.

He was a young man during Pyrrhus’ invasion of Laconia, 272 BC, but he took part in the fightingc.

He led the Lacedaemonian army to Megalopolis and was killed there, ca. 262 BC, by Aristodemos, the tyranta.

Ἀκρότατος (3) END III BC

IG IX2 29

Father of —ai (Fragment 8), a Lacedaemoni[an]

Ἀλεξάνδρ[α] ROMAN PERIOD

IG V 1. 770 (Ἀλκιλάδα ǀ Ἀλεξάνδρ[α]ς or Ἀλέξανδρ[ο]ς)

Mother of Alkida{m}a? or Alexandros (2), son of Alkiladas?

Ἀλεξανδρίδας, Poralla 49a; see Ἀναξανδρίδας II

Ἀλεξανδρίδας IV BC

IG V 2. 549

Father of Seleidas, a Lacedaemonian

Ἀλέξανδρος

Athenaeus IV 183c

From Cythera

The perfecter of the psaltery

Ἀλέξανδρος V\IV BC

Poralla 50; Polyaenus VI 10; (date: Xenophon Hellenica IV 8.18-19)

As phrouarch an Alexandros handed over the fortified places of Aeolis to the Spartan commander Thibron. The time is established through the mention of the flute player Thersandros who is appropriate only to the second Asian campaign of Thibron. That Alexandros was Lacedaemonian is probable.

Ἀλέξανδρος BEGINNING IV BC

Poralla 51; Diodorus XV 64.2

A Spartiate who in the winter 370/69 fell on the border of Laconia in a

battle against the Argives

Ἀλέξανδ[ρος] (1) END II AD OR LATER

Son of Alexandros (4)

Subject of an honorary decree

Ἀλεξίππα MID IV BC

Poralla 52; Anthologia Palatina VII 435

Wife of Iphikratidas, mother of Eupylidas, Eraton, Chairis, Lykos, Agis, Alexon and Gylippos (all killed before Messene)

Ἀλεξιππίδας END V BC

Poralla 53; Xenophon Hellenica II 3.10; Thucydides VIII 58

Ἄλεξις END I AD

IG V 1. 51a, [52]b; [SEG XI 562]c

Son of Philokrates (10)abc

[Gerousias]c

Ἀλεξίων (1) MID II AD

IG V 1. 161

Son of (Alexion <2>)

Name in a catalogue

(Ἀλεξίων [2]) I\II AD

IG V 1. 161

Father of Alexion (1)

Μᾶρκος Αὐρήλιος Ἀλέξυς MID II or EARLY III AD

Rizakas 87; IG V 1. 817

Son of Theon (3)

Killed in a war against the Parthians (during the reign of either M. Aurelius or Caracalla—preferred by Spawforth, ABSA 79, 267-9) at the age of thirty; a relief shows him armed with spear, sword, and shield

Ἀλέξων MID IV BC

Poralla 54; Anthologia Palatina VII 435

Son of Iphikratidas and Alexippa; he is supposed to have fallen with his brothers Eupylidas, Eraton, Chairis, Lykos, Agis, and Gylippos before Messene

ΑΛΚ—, see Μέτριος
Ἀλκαθόα END VI BC

Poralla 55; Scholia to Aristophanes Equites 84; Suidas s. v. Παυσανίας (Ἀγειθέα); Polyaenus VIII 51 (Θεανώ); Diodorus XI 45,6; Nepos Pausanias 5,3

Mother of Pausanias and so also the mother of Nikomedes and wife of Kleombrotos. The different forms of the name most likely refer back to one form with ΘΕΑ or ΘΟΑ. She is supposed to have brought a brick when her son Pausanias was in the temple of Athena Chalkioikos to wall him up.

Ἀλκαμένης VIII BC

Poralla 56; Herodotus VII 204; Pausanias III 2.7, IV 4.4; FGrH (Apollodorus Chronika) II 244 (86/7)

Agid king

Son of Teleklos and father of Polydoros.

The chronographers made him an older contemporary of Theopompos and concluded that the First Messenian War began under him. His reign was supposed to have been 32 years long, 785/4-754/3.

Ἀλκαμένης MID V BC

Poralla 57; Thucydides VIII 5, 8, 10

Son of the ephor Sthenlaidas, led an army in 412 to king Agis II at Decelea. He was supposed to sail a fleet to Chios but he was repulsed by the Athenians at the Peiraeus and in the following battle was killed.

Ἀλκαμένης (1) DIED 220 BC

Polybius IV 22.11

A Lacedaemonian murdered by the pro-Aetolian faction in Sparta

Ἀλκαμένης (2) III BC

IG V 1. 29

Father of Gorgis

Ἀλκαμένης (3) II\I BC

IG V 1. [49], 95, 212

Father of Kleandros (1)

[Ἀλ]κανδρίδας (1) I\II AD

IG V 1. 78

Son of ([Al]kandridas <5>)

Boua[go]s and grammatophylax

Nomophylax in the year of Me(mmius) — (4)

Πό(πλιος) Αἴλιος Ἀλκανδρίδας (2) II\III AD

Rizakis 6; IG V 1. 304a, 556b, [655 (cf. SEG XI 831)]c, [682 (cf.

SEG XI 844)]d; SEG XI 499e, 803f; IOlymp 238g; Orthia 330, 63h

Son of Damokratidas (3)bfg

Twice periodonikes and victor in many contestsbcf, dedication at Olympia for victory, ca. AD 221 and 225g, “best of the Greeks”bcf

Philocaesar, patriot, high priest of the emperorsabf, presbys of bideoi and subject of an honorary decree for his favors to his countryb; gymnasiarch and subject of an honorary decree for his acts as gymnasiarchf; [bideos]d; agoranomose

Eponymous patronomosabh

[2a] He is also to be recognized in the patronymic Alkandrida of P. Aelius Damocratidas in IG V 1. 305 = Bourguet, 130-32, no. 44 and in the following honorary inscriptions (all Severan)

[b-d.B] IG V 1. 553, 554, 555a, 555b and presumably

[e] A. M.Woodward ABSA 26, 1923-25, 211-12 no. 10 with facsimile (XI 802)

[f] The same [?] should be postulated as father of P. Aelius Damocratidas in IG V 1. 655 (emended by L. Robert, REA 31, 1929, 13-18 and supplemented with two fragments by A. M. Woodward, ABSA 29, 1927-28, 41-43 no 65 with facsimile [XI 831], Spawforth, ABSA 79, 1984, 273

Remarks: Bradford distinguishes [1. 2f] [= p. 26 (2) from the Alcandridas of [2a-e] [= p. 27 (6)] regarding the latter as th grandfather of the former, whom he identifies with P. Aelius Alcandridas (III), son of Damocratidas, the prominent Spartan athlete and magistrate of the 1st half of the 3rd c. AD. This is rejected by A. J. S. Spawforth ABSA 80, 1985, 246, 247 n. 147, because he dates [1] in the 3rd quarter of the 2nd c. AD. He considers [1. 2a-e] as P. Aelius Alcandridas (II), the grandfather of P. Aelius Alcandridas (III). Settipani, 496 places his lifetime from AD 130 to after AD 155/65.

For the board of agranomoi in [1] see A. S. Bradford Chiron 10, 1980, 416 n. 33 and N. M. Kennell ZPE 85, 1991, 135n. 15.

Perhaps s. P. Aelius Nicandridas (LAC 16) and probably grands. P. Aelius Alcandridas (I) (LAC 5), presumably h. Pompeia Polla (I) (LAC 613) by whom f. P. Aelius Damocrates (LAC 9), grandf. P. Aelius Alcandridas (III) (LAC 7), perhaps also natural grandf. Ti. Claudius Aelius Partolaus (II) also known as Damocratidas (LAC 251); cf. stemmata in A. J. S. Spawforth, ABSA 80, 1985, 246 tab. 6 (Aelii Alcandridas and Settipani, 496 (the most important families of Roman Sparta); see infra, Appendix, Stemmata I and II.

Κλαύ(διος) Ἀλκανδρίδας (3) END II AD

Rizakis 255 (ca AD 267); IG V 1. 593

Son of (Claudius —) and Julia Etearchis

Brother of Claudia Elpis (1) he kai Kallistonike

He and his sister paid for a memorial to their mother.

[Πό(πλιος) Αἴλ(ιος)] Ἀλκ[ανδ]ρίδας β[ουαγός] (4) MID II AD

Rizakis 5; SEG XI 550; A. J. S. Spawforth, ABSA 80, 1985, 247 (cf. SEG 35, 1985, 328) [AD 140s]

Enseito[s] in the year of [C. Julius Eudamos <6>], AD 139/40-ca. 142

=

Π(όπλιος) Αἴλιος [Ἀλκανδρί]δα[ς] REIGN OF HADRIAN

Steinhauer, BSA 93, pp. 427-447, #3, plate 72a SEG 48, 1998, 457, l. 6;

AnnEpigr 1998, 1240 [AD 136/37]

Bo[uagos]

Gerousias [for the second or more time] in the year of Nike[phoros h]o [Markou].

“Remarks: The date of the first is based on prosopographical considerations (Woodward loc. cit and A. J. S. Spawforth, ABSA 80, 1985, 210-11 n. 69). Which leads A. M. Woodward to restore the lost name of the eponymous official by analogy with IG V 1. 63 ll. 16-17, a catalogue of ephors in the term of C. Julius Eudamos, A. J. S. Spawforth, ABSA 80, 1985, 27 convincingly restores [Πό(πλιος) Αἴλ(ιος)] Ἀλκ[ανδ]ρίδας β[ουαγός] in [1. 1.16]. If this restoration is correct, prosopographically he is the earliest known and otherwise unattested member of this family with Roman citizenship, hence P. Aelius Alcandridas (1). Considering the chronological evidence of this inscription, it is most likely that he had become a Roman citizen through a personal grant of Hadrian on the occasion of one of the emperor’s two visits at Sparta (in AD 124/5 and 128/9). Cf. W. Weber, Untersuchungen zur Geschichte des Kaisers Hadrianus (Leipzig 1907)188-89 n. 671. 211 ns. 744-45; H. Box JRS 21 1931, 201; Chrimes Ancient Sparta 465; Halfmann Itinera principum, 137, 192; Cartledge and Spawforth 108. This would mean that Alcandridas was already of advanced age when ensitos.

“An unpublished inscription discussed in Steinhauer Eurykles testifies that C. Julius Eurykles Herculanus (LAC 462, ARC 105) died in the patronomate of (C. Julius) Nicephoros son of Marcus attested in [2], which should be dated to ca. AD 136/7, see G. Steinhauer, ABSA 93, 1998, 431 n 9. This date allows the identification of P. Aelius Alcandridas in [2] with the homonymous person in [1].

“For the nature of the post and title of bouagos [1(?), 2] in the Spartan agoge of the Roman imperial period see Cartledge and Spawforth, esp 203-204; Kennell, Institutions, 181-85 and id., Gymnasium esp 41-42, 108-09. Perhaps f. P. Aelius Nikandridas (LAC 16) see stemma in Spawforth, op. cit., 246 tab 6 (Aelii Alcandridae); see infra, Appendix, Stemma II.”

Ἀλκέτης V\IV BC

Poralla 59; Xenophon Hellenica V 4.56-57; Polyaenus II 7

As harmost he lost Oreos in Winter 377/6 and he was condemned for

his carelessness in the loss of this important place.

Ἀλκιβία I BC

IG V 1. 141a, 465b, 578c

Daughter of Teisamenos (6)abc

Wife of Damippos (1)bc

Mother of Teisamenos (2)b

Man(tis) and [hi]erothytes in the year of Aristokratidas (1)a

Subject of an honorary decree for her domestic virtue, the benefactions of her ancestors, and the blameless life she led with her husband for sixty years.c

Ἀλκιβιάδης MID V BC

Poralla 60; Thucydides VIII 6

Father of Endios (who belonged to the college of ephors in 413/2)

[Ἀλ]κιβιάδ[ης] (1) END VI BC

SEG XXVII (1977) 135; G. Daux, Études Delphique (BCH supplement 4, Paris, 1977) 51-57 (photo)

Dedication to Apollo at Delphi, 525-500 BC?

Laconian

Grandfather of Poralla #60?

Ἀλκιβιάδης (2) III\II BC

Livy XXXIX 35.6-37.21; Pausanias VII 9.2-4; Polybius XXII 1.9, 11.7-12.4; XXIII 4.3

A Lacedaemonian of great distinction who was exiled by Nabis and restored by the Achaean League

He was an envoy to the Romans in 184 BC, during which mission he denounced the Achaeans.

Ἀλκίδας MID VI BC

Poralla 61; Herodotus VI 61

Father of the Spartiate Agetos (the friend of the king Ariston)

Ἀλκίδας MID V BC

Poralla 62; Thucydides III 16, 26, 29-33a, 69, 76-81b, 92c; Diodorus XII 55.6d

Nauarch of the year 428/7

He was supposed to relieve Mytilene in the spring of 427, but he delayed so much on the trip, that at Delos the news reached him of the fall of Mytilene.

After a few voyages here and there along the coast of Asia Minor, he met a superior Athenian force and fled back to the Peloponnesusad. From Cyllene (where Brasidas was his military adviser) he sailed to Corcyra in the summer of 427.

After an indecisive sea battle he escaped from the Athenian fleet over the Isthmus of Leukasb.

In 426 Alkidas went as founder to Herakleia in Trachisc.

Ἀλκίδας V\IV BC

Poralla 63; Diodorus XV 46.1-3

Nauarch of the year 374/3. He was apparently despatched to Sicily and

on the way was supposed to ravage Corcyra. The attack miscarried.

Ἀλκίδας VICTOR 240 BC

Eusebius Chronicorum Libri II (ed. A. Schoene), I, 207, 208

Victor in the stadion during the 134th Olympiad

Ἀλκιλάδας? ROMAN PERIOD

(or Alkida{m}a, daughter of Alexandra)

again under Argillos 361/360.

Ἀλκμάν LATER VII BC

Poralla 67; Bergk Poetae Lyrici Graeci III p 46, fr 24a; Herakleides Pontikos II 2 in Müller, Fragmenta Historicorum Graecorum, Paris, 1878, II p 210b; Suidas s. v.c; Anthologia Palatina VII 19, 709d; SEG XXIX 388 (S. E. Waywell, American Journal of Archaeology, 83 <1979>, 303, #49): mosaic portrait bust, associated with Sappho and Anacreone; Aelian varia historia XII 50; The Partheneion (D. L. Page), Oxford, 1951; Alcmani, I frammenti (Antonio Garzya), Naples, 1954; Antonio Farina, Studi sul Partenio di Alcmane, Naples, 1950; Athenaeus I 31cd, II 39a, III 81d, f, 110f, 111a, 114f, 115a, IV 140c, IX 373e, 374d, 390a, X 416cd, XI 498f-499a, XIII 600f, XIV 624b, [636d], 637a, 638e, 646a, 648b, XV 678c, 680f, 681a, XV 682a; Pausanias I 41.4, III 15.2, 3, 18.6, 26.2; Plutarch Lycurgus 28.10, Sulla 36.5, Moralia (de fortuna Romanorum) 318a, (de exilio 2) 599e, (quaestionum convivalium II 10.2) 659b, (de Herodoti malignitate 14) 857f, (aetia physica 24) 918a, (de facie in orbe lunae) 940a; Aristotle historia animalium 557a2; PW Supplement XI 19-29

The poet of Laconian choral lyric from the second half of the seventh century. Over his antecedents there is no agreement. (1) Alcman came from Sardisa. Added to that is the reference that Alcman was the slave of the Lacedaemonian Agesidasb. (2) Elsewherec the poet is described as Λάκων ἀπὸ Μεσσόας and is given Damas or Titaros as his father. (3) Ale­xan­der the Aetoliand takes a middle position in an epigram; he holds Alcman for a Laconian, but says that his ancestors came from Sardis. In a mosaic portrait bust Alcman was associated with Sappho and Anacreone.

Ἀλκυονεῦς REIGN OF ANTONINUS PIUS

Steinhauer, BSA 93, pp. 427-447, #4, plate 72b

Son of Nikon

Kasen to Eurykles

Gerousias for the second time in the year of P. Mem(mius) Eudamos

Ἀλύπητος V\IV BC

Poralla 68; Xenophon Hellenica V 4.52

Fell in 377 as polemarch in the army of Agesilaos before Thebes

Ἀλφειός VI\V BC

Poralla 69; Herodotus VII 227 (Ἀλφεός); Pausanias III 12.9

Son of Orsiphantos

He fell together with his brother Maron in 480 at Thermopylae and had a memorial in Sparta

Αὐρ(ήλιος) Ἀλφειός II\III AD

Rizakis 88; IG V 1. 546

Subject of an honorary decree as epi[tropos] of the emperors for his good will towards the Lacedaemonians

Probably not Lacedaemonian

Ἀλώπεκος PRE-LITERATE

Poralla 70; Pausanias III 16.9

Son of Irbos and brother of Astrabakos.

He is supposed to have been the fourth descendant of Agis I.

Ἀμεινίας END V BC

Poralla 71; Thucydides IV 132

Ἀμίαντος MID I BC

Son of Aristonikos (4)

AMMAIO[Σ], IG V 1. 40, error for [γρ]αμματόφυλαξ, see SEG XI 482

Ἀμομφάρητος END VII BC

Poralla 72; Plutarch Solon 10

One of the five Spartan arbiters who awarded Salamis to the Athenians around 610

Ἀμομφάρητος ca. 508-479 BC

Poralla 73; Herodotus IX 53-57, 71, 85; Plutarch Aristides 17

Son of Poliades

In 479 he fought in the battle of Plataea as leader of the Pitanatans and fell there, before he was 30 years old. His initial refusal to obey the command to retreat before the Persians brought on the battle. He was judged to be the bravest of the Spartans.

Ἀμπελίδας END V BC

Poralla 74; Thucydides V 22

As ambassador to Argos shortly before 421 he tried to renew the thirty

years truce

Ἀμύκλα MID V BC

Poralla 75; Plutarch Alcibiades 1, Lycurgus 16, cf. Λανίκη

The nurse of Alcibiades

Ἀμύκλαι[ος]

Father (?) of —a (Fragment 11)

IG V 1. 136

Son of T— (1)

Bidyos in the year of D— (2)

Ἀμφάρης MID III BC

Plutarch Agis 18.7-21.1

An ephor, who, under the pretense of being a friend, lured Agis IV from his sanctuary, conducted him to prison, prosecuted and executed the king, the king’s mother, Agesistrata, and grandmother, Archidamia

Ἀμφιάρης IV\III BC

The Oxyrhyncus Papyri, ed. Arthur S. Hunt, London, 1927, Part XVII, Number 2082; L. Moretti, Olympionikai, Lincei, 1955, page 133, number 515

Olympic victor in wrestling, 296 BC

Father of Aristodamas

Ἀμφικλῆς PRE-LITERATE

Poralla 76; Pausanias III 16,9

Son of Agis I

Father of Amphisthenes

He belongs, as do his descendants, to a fictitious series of Spartans who serve only to tie the Spartan hero Astrabakos to the royal line.

Poralla 77; IG V 1. 1121

Ἀμφισθένης

Poralla 78; Pausanias III 16.9

Son of Amphikles

Father of Irbos

He belongs, as do his descendants, to a fictitious series of Spartans who

serve only to tie the Spartan hero Astrabakos to the royal line.

Ἀν— (4)

IG V 1. 171 (Upon examination of the squeeze at the Prussian Academy I found no trace of a P, only scratches more like scars. The P I suspect is due to the too acute desire of the epigrapher to read traces; if this is a name, then it is AN—.)

ἈναΟ— I BC

IG V 1. 125

Eponymous patronomos in the year before Damarchos (3)

Ἀναξάνδρα PRE-LITERATE

Poralla 79; Pausanias III 16.6

Daughter of the mythical king Thersandros of Kleonai, twin sister of Lathria

The pair were married to the sons of Aristodemos, Eurysthenes and Prokles.

Ἀναξανδρίδας I VII\VI BC

Poralla 80; Herodotus VIII 131

King from the house of the Eurypontids

Son of king Theopompos

Father of Archidamos I

His reign falls at the turn of the seventh century.

Ἀναξανδρίδας II MID VI BC

Poralla 81; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v.

Ἀναξανδρίδας) 216f-217b; Herodotus I 67-8, V 39-41; Pausanias

III 3.5-6, 9

King from the house of the Agids

Son of king Leon

In his first marriage he wed the daughter of his sister. Childless, he was compelled to take a second wife (the daugher of Prinetadas), by whom he had the later king Kleomenes I. By his first wife he then had Dorieus, Leonidas, and Kleombrotos.

Anaxandridas was the contemporary of Croesus and Ariston. He reigned from about 550-516.

Under him the long war with Tegea was ended.

Ἀνάξανδρος VII BC

Poralla 82; Herodotus VII 204; Pausanias III 3.4-5, 14.4, IV 15ff

King from the house of the Agids

Son of Eurykrates

Father of Eurykratidas

His wife’s name was Leandris. Pausanias puts him in the time of the

second Messenian war.

Ἀνάξανδρος END V BC

Poralla 83; Olymp 327; Pausanias VI 1.7

He was a victor in the Olympic games (Olympiad 88 = 428 BC ?) with the four horse chariot where also his father’s father had won in the Pentathlon.

Ἀνάξανδρος MID IV BC

Poralla 84; Diodorus XVI 39.6

Around 351 as leader of a Spartan detachment he was captured by the

allied Thebans and Argives near Telphusa

Ἀναξίβιος (Ϝαναξίβιος) VI BC

Poralla 85; IG V 1. 215

Retrograde inscription: a dedication

Ἀναξίβιος V\IV BC

Poralla 86; Xenophon Anabasisa V 1.4, VI 1.16, VII 1.10-20 2.4-8;

Hellenica IV 8.32-39b; Diodorus XIV 30.4c

Nauarch of the year 401/400.

In the spring of 400 he and his fleet were at Byzantium. He attempted to hinder the 10,000 from crossing into Europe (with one eye on the Persians)ac.

Around 389/8 he came to the Hellespont as harmost of Abydos. He was caught there by Iphicrates’ expedition to Abydos and fell in battleb.

Ἀναξίδαμος VII BC

Poralla 87; Pausanias III 7.6, IV 15.3

Collateral relative of the house of the Eurypontids

Son of Zeuxidamos

Father of an Archidamos.

According to the sus­pect list of Pausanias he was king at the end of the

second Messenian war.

Ἀναξίλας MID VII BC

Poralla 88; Herodotus VIII 131

King from the house of the Eurypontids

Son of Archidamos I

Father of Leotychidas I

He may have ruled about the middle of the seventh century.

Ἀναξίλας END VII BC

Poralla 89; Plutarch Solon 10

He spoke as one of the five Spartan arbiters who awarded Salamis to

Athens in 610.

Ἀναφ—

IG V 1. 1505

Father of [Ar]ch[i]pos (1)?

Ἀνδρόβολος III BC

IG V 1. 29

Father of Damaisidas

Ἀνδροκλείδας

Poralla 91; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v.) 217c

A Lacedaemonian of unknown time who has a saying in Plutarch about

his lameness in battle

Ἀνδρόμαχος VICTOR 56 BC

Eusebius Chronica (ed. A. Schoene) I, 211, 212

(Lacedaemonian or Ambraciot) victor in the stadion during the

180th Olympiad

Ἀνδρομέδης END V BC

Poralla 92; Thucydides V 42

Was sent as ambassador to Boeotia and Athens in 420

Ἀνδρομέδης BEGINNING IV BC

Poralla 93; IG V 1. 1232

the fourth century in the time of the ephor Eudamidas

Ἀνδροτελία (2) II-I BC

SEG XI 677c (addenda et corrigenda)

Ἀνέγκλητος MID II AD

IG V 1. 53a, [54]b

Son of Euporistosa

Father of Stephanos (1)a

[Gra]mmato[phylax] in the year of Se[x. Pom]peius — (3)b. i.e.

[Theoxenos or Brasidas (4)?]

Ephor in the year of Kallikrates (26)a, AD 151/2

Ἀνήριστος END VI BC

Poralla 94; Herodotus VII 134

Father of the Spartiate Sperthias, who was sent to Xerxes in 480

Ἀνήριστος MID V BC

Poralla 95; Thucydides II 67; Herodotus VII 134, 137

Son of Sperthias

He was instrumental in the campaign at Halieis, perhaps in 459, against

the Athenians.

In 430 he went to the king of Thrace Sitalkes to try to win him over to the Spartan side, but he was taken prisoner by Sadokos, the son of Sitalkes and handed over to the Athenians who executed him.

Ἀνθεστία ROMAN PERIOD

Rizakis 25 (I A.D.); IG V 1. 756

Gravemarker

Μ(ᾶρκος) Ἀνθέστιος Φιλοκράτης (6)
Ἀνθεσφόρος REIGN OF ANTONINUS PIUS

IG V 1. 65; SEG XI 523; Steinhauer, BSA 93, pp. 427-447, #8, plate 75a

Father of Telesphoros

Ἄνθης END VI BC

Poralla 96; Stephanus Byzantius s. v. Ἀνθάνα; Alan Griffiths, ‟Was Cleomenes Mad,” Classical Sparta: Techniques Behind Her Success, Norman, 1988, pp. 62-67

He was supposed to have been flayed by Kleomenes I. Stephanus identifies Anthes with the mythical founder of Anthana, the son of Poseidon (and not a Lacedaemonian) and suggests some sort of symbolic act.

“Kalas [An]thida set up this memorial to [G]laukat[ias] his son”

Ἀνείκητο[ς] (2) I\II AD

SEG XI 497

Ἄννα Ἀφροδείτω

IG V 1. 812

Wife of Beithys

Mother of Gergyllion

Gravemarker for herself, Beithys, and Gergyllion

(Aphrodeito may be the genitive of Aphrodeitos, hence, Anna, the

daughter of Aphrodeitos)

Ἄνσετ[ος] (1) I BC

IG V 1. 207

Eponymous patronomos

Ἄνσε[τος] (2) I BC

IG V 1. 266

Aristokr[ates (3) kasen to him in the year of Mena]lkid[as] (3)

Ἀντ— ROMAN PERIOD

IG V 1. 744

Parent of Damokratis

Ἀνταλκίδας V\IV BC

Poralla 97; Plutarch Artaxerxes 21-22a; Agesilaus 23b, 32c; Xenophon Hellenica IV 8.12-16d; V 1.6, 25-29, 36e; VI 3.12f; Diodorus XIV 110g; Athenaeus II 48e; David Whitehead, Liverpool Classical Monthly IV (1979), 191-193, on the form of the name

Son of Leona

His mother was probably Teleutia.

In winter 393/2 he travelled to Sardis to the satrap Tiribazos from whom he received money for support of the fleetd. As nauarch of the year 388/7 he sailed from Aigina to Ephesus and betook himself to the Great King with whom he worked out the terms of the peace named after himeg.

After that he relieved Nikolochos who had been shut up in Abydose.

At the time of the 371 peace conference in Sparta he was spending time at the court of the Persian kingf.

In 370/69 he held the office of ephorc.

It was probably in 367 that he travelled for the third time to the king. There, however, when his mission was fruitless, he committed suicidea.

IG V 1. 1226

Father of Philon (2), a Lacedaemonian

Ἀντικλῆς I BC

IG V 1. 208

Father of Pantias (1)

Ἀντικλείδας

Poralla 98; Scholia to Euripides Hippolytus 230

Father of Leon, who won a victory with his father’s horses

Ἀντικράτης MID IV BC

Poralla 99; Plutarch Agesilaus 35; Pausanias VIII 11.5

A Spartiate who at the battle of Mantinea in 362 killed Epaminondas and thereby won the title of Machairion and public meals for his descendants.

Ἀντικράτης REIGN OF AUGUSTUS

Steinhauer, BSA 93, pp. 427-447, #1, plate 71a

Father of Agiadas

IG V 1. 162A

Son of ([An]tiochos <2>)

Ἄντιππος END V BC

Poralla 103; Thucydides V 19, 24

He was one of the Spartiates who concluded the Peace of Nicias and

the alliance with Athens in 421.

Ἀντισθένης V\IV BC

Poralla 104; Thucydides VIII 39, 42; Xenophon Hellenica III 2.6-9

A Spartiate who in the winter of 412/11 travelled from Laconia to Knidos with a fleet and united with the nauarch Astyochos. In Spring 398 we find him in Lampsakos with Derkylidas.

Ἀντίωρος LYCURGAN AGE

Poralla 105; Plutarch Lycurgus 31

Son of the lawgiver Lycurgus

He can only be as historical as Lycurgus himself

Ἀντωνία Δυναμίς

Cartledge and Spawforth, 110-11, 186: quinquennial games begun in 136/7))

Ἀνυστίς MID IV BC

Poralla 106; Pliny naturalis historia VII 84; Solinus I 98

A runner from Lacedaemon in the time of Alexander the Great. (He ran 1200 stades in one day.)

Ἰουλ(ί)α Ἀπατάριον II AD

Ἀπήγα III\II BC

Polybius XIII 7.[2] and 6; [XVIII 17.2-5]

Wife of Nabis

Possibly she is to be identified with Apia, the daughter of Aristippos, tyrant of Argos (IG IV2 621; A. Wilhelm, “Hellenistisches,” Anzeiger der Akademie der Wissenschaften in Wien, Philosoph.-hist. Klasse, LVIII [1921], 70-73).

Ἀπολλ[όδωρος] REIGN OF ANTONINUS PIUS

Steinhauer, BSA 93, pp. 427-447, #5b, plate 73b, restores the name (a very short one) of the patronomos from IG V. 111 ( = SEG XI 584), a gerousias named C. Julius Neas. (see Apollonios)

Ἀπολλωνία ROMAN PERIOD

IG III 2. 2560

Daughter of Apollonius (who was not a Lacedaemonian)

She was a Magnesian?

Gravemarker in Attica

Ἀπολλωνίδας (1) DIED 181 BC

Polybius XXIV 7.6-8

One of the auditors of the funds which Chairon (2) was misappropriating. He was murdered by Chairon’s hirelings.

Λούκιος Ἀπρώνιος Ἀκίνδυνος

Λούκιος Ἀπρώνιος Εὐελπίστος (2)

(Λο)ύκιος Ἀπρώνιος Πρασιμένης (1)
ΑΡ 219-196 BC

Grunauer, Gruppe VIII, Serie 6 (), Tafel 4 (22-26)

Name on a coin—perhaps the mint official but more likely the holder of

the eponymous office, at this date probably the eponymous patronomos

Ἄρακος V/IV BC

Poralla 107; Xenophon Hellenica II 3.10.1a,7b; III 2.6-9c; VI 5.33d; Pausanias X 9.9e; Plutarch Lysander 7f; FDelph III I 51g (epigram)

Eponymous ephor of the year 409/8a. Nominal nauarch of the year 405/4b. In spring 398 with Naubates and Antisthenes he was sent to Dercylidas in Asia Minorc. In winter 370/69 he was an ambassador in Athensd. (But is the ambassador a second Arakos?)

Ἀράτα (1)

IG V 1. 579

Daughter of Tycharetos

Subject of an honorary decree for her sensible and pious life; dedication

to Demeter and Kore

Ἀράτα (2) MID IV BC

Poralla 108; IG IV2 122 xxi ( = SIG3 1169 xxi)

[La]kaina

A sufferer from dropsy. Her mother went to the shrine of Asclepius in Epidaurus to find a cure. In her sleep she saw Asclepius decapitate her daughter—a liquid flowed from her head—and he rejoined head and neck. The mother hurried home to Sparta, found her daughter cured, and the dream fulfilled.

Ἄρατος VIII BC

Poralla 109; Justin III 4.8

Father of Phalanthos (according to myth the founder of Tarentum)

Ἄρατος (1) I BC

IG V 1. 211

Son of Dexikrates

Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristokratidas (1)

Ἄρατος (2) AFTER MID II BC

IG V 1. 961

Son of Nikias (16)

A Lacedaemonian honored by Cotyrta for his benefactions. He and his descendants were granted the rights of proxenos and benefactor: to own land and a house, to contract marriage, to have the protection of law, exemption, asylum in war and peace, and the other customary rights.

Ἄρα[τος] (3) I BC

IG V 1. 94

Father of Lykomedes

Ἄρα[τος] (4) IV-III BC

SEG XI 668

Dedication to Athena

[Ἀ-- or Πε]ργενίδας II BC

SEG XI 681

Son of Aristomenidas (3)

Vow to the Dioscuri

Ἀργιλεωνίς MID V BC

Poralla 110; Plutarch Lycurgus 25, Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica

s. v. Brasidas 4) 219d

Wife of Tellis and mother of the famous Brasidas

Ἄργιος REIGN OF DOMITIAN

IG V 1. 152 (cf. SEG XI 604) {i. e. Ἄρειος or Ἄργ(ε)ιος?}

Son of Eros (2)

Name in a catalogue [of bideoi?], ca. AD 81-85

Argolicus I BC\I AD

Tacitus Annales VI 18.2

Son of C. Julius Lakon (1)

Husband of Pompeia Makrina

He fell into disfavor with Tiberius and was ruined.

IG V 1. 211a; VII 420b

Son of Lysippos (9)ab

Aurelius Aristokrates (8)

ΔΟΥΤΕΛ Ἀρέτων (4) REIGN OF CARACALLA

Rizakis 370; IG V 1. 666, cf. SEG XI 836— ΔΟΥΤΕΛ = {Λ}ού(κιος) {Γ}έλ(λιος) or {Λ}(ούκιος) Οὐ{ι}τέλ(λιος) or {Μ(ᾶρκος) A}ὐ{ρή}λ(ιος)

Agonothetes of the Eurycleian games

Ἄρευς END VI BC

Poralla 112; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v.) 217f

A Laconian who made a remark on an epigram about the tyranny in

Selinus (i.e., time of Dorieus’ expedition {?}, see Euryleon 327)

Ἄρευς

Poralla 113; Antoninus Liberalis 12 = Pausanias III 13.8 Areios

Laconian poet of unknown time (but PW Supplement I 127:

“Areios” is probably Asinos (of Samos), not Areus)

Ἄρευς (1) I REIGN 309-265 BC

Diodorus Siculus XX 29.1a; Justin XXIV 1.5; Pompeius Trogus prologi 26; Pausanias I 13.5; III 6.2-6b; VI 12.5-6, 15.9; Plutarch Agis 3.6-7c, Pyrrhus 26.17-19d, 27.2e, 29.11f, 30.4, Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica) 217fg; Josephus Antiquitates Judaicae XII 225-27h, XIII 167 (ΑΡΕΙΟΣ); 1 Maccabees 12.1-23; Athenaeus IV 142b; ICret II xxiii 12Ai; IOlymp 308j; IG IV 1. 332; SEG XXV 444k; SEG XI 668 (?—Dedication to Athena); [SIG3 430, see Areus (2) II]; Grunauer, pp. 112-113 (Gr. I-II, Tafel 1: ΒΑΣΥΛΕΟΣ ΑΡΕΟΣ)

Son of Akrotatos (1)

Grandson of Kleomenes II

Father of Akrotatos (2), king of Sparta

Agiad king of Spartaa, 309-265 BCbc

He succeeded to the throne despite the fact that Kleonymos (1), son of Kleomenes II, was alive. Kleonymos, however, was given command of the armies. Their rivalry, intensified, no doubt, by Akrotatos’ adultery with the wife of Kleonymos, led to Kleonymos’ leaving Sparta and joining Pyrrhus.bd

Areus was an active king, forming connections in Sicilyg, Creteei, Egyptjk, and possibly Judaeah.

He attempted to restore the Spartan hegemony of the Peloponnesus and opposed the Macedonian forces in Greece, although he was forced into a brief alliance with them to forestall the invasion of Pyrrhus into Laconiaf.

He was killed in an attempt to force the Macedonian lines at Corinth, 265 BCc

Ἄρευς (2) II 262-254 BC

SIG3 430; Pausanias III 6.6; Plutarch Agis 3.7-8; [Pyrrhus 26.17-18]

In SIG3 430 the Delphians grant proxenia to “King Areus, son of King Akrotatos and Queen Chilonis.” The editor believes that this refers to Areus I, since it seemed unlikely to him that the Delphians would grant proxenia to a child, albeit a king. Akrotatos, however, the father of Areus I, was not a king. There is but one king Akrotatos and he is the father of Areus II. Moreover, the Chilonis of the inscription might well be the widow of Kleonymus and lover of Akrotatos the king [26.17-18].)

Son of Akrotatos (2) and Chilonis (1)

Grandson of Areus (1) I

He was born after the death of his father at Megalopolis, 262 BC. Leonidas (1), the son of Kleonymos (1), was regent. He was an Agiad king.

He died of disease when he was eight years old.

Ἄρευς (3) III\II BC

Livy XXXIX 35-37; Pausanias VII 9.2-4; Polybius XXII 1.9 & 11.7-12.4; XXIII 4.3

Of royal descent?

He was exiled from Sparta by Nabis and restored against the wishes of the government of Sparta by the Achaean league.

In 184 BC he was an envoy to the Romans and he denounced the Achaean league.

Τ(ίτος) Τρεβελληνός Ἄρευς (4) I AD

Rizakis 699; IG V 1. 20ba; SEG XI 511b, 608c

Son of Polemarchosa

Father of T. Trebellenus Menekles (1)bc

Ephora [in the year of Menekles, AD 96/7]

Ἀρηξίδαμος DIED 207 BC

Polybius XI 18.3-5

A companion (bodyguard?) of Machanidas at the battle of Mantinea, 207 BC, where he was killed

Lacedaemonian?

Ἀρ[ή]ξιππος BEGINNING IV BC

Poralla 114; IG V 1. 255; Orthia 1 (p. 296), Moretti IAG 18

Victor of the boys’ games (apparently five times)

ΑΡΙ 219-196 BC

Grunauer, Gruppe VIII, Serie 5 (), Tafel 4 (19, 21)

Name on a coin—perhaps the mint official but more likely the holder of

the eponymous office, at this date probably the eponymous patronomos

Grunauer, p. 53 (emission mark 8 ), Gruppe XIV (48-40 BC), Serie 12, Tafel 8, Gruppe XV (48-40 BC), Serie 12-13, Tafel 9, Gruppe XVI (43-31 BC), Serie 3, Tafel 11, Gruppe XVII (43-31 BC), Serie 2, Tafel 13 suggests Aristokratidas, Aristomachos, or Aristokles

Name on a coin—perhaps the mint official but more likely the holder of an office, gerousias, ephor, or eponymous patronomos

Ἀρισταγόρας (1) II BC

IG V 1. 965

Son of Agexenos

Lacedaemonian

Honored by Cotyrta for his benefactions. He and his descendants were granted the status of proxenos and benefactor with the right to hold land and a house, to have legal recourse, asylum in war and peace, to be invited to the public festivals, to have the major rights of hospitality and the other customary rights

Ἀρισταγόρας (2) I AD

SEG XI 515

Father of Dinokratidas

The Flinders Petrie Papyri, Part 2, ed. J. P. Mahaffy (Royal Irish Academy, Cunningham Memoirs, Number 9), Dublin, 1891-1905, II 35 (a), column I, line 6

Mercenary Lacedaemonian cavalryman in Egypt, ca. 240 BC

shortly after 404/3bc.

Ἀριστόδαμος VIII-VII BC?

Poralla 122; Diogenes Laertius I 30-31; Scholia to Pindar Isthmia II 17; Bergk Poetae Lyrici Graeci III Alkaios fr 49 (now E. Lobel and D. L. Page, Poetarum Lesbiorum Fragmenta, 1955); Zenobius VI 43

A Spartiate who was reckoned one of the seven wise men

Ἀριστόδαμος V BC

Poralla 123; IG V 1. 1356

Priest

Name from an inscription (Fourmont) originating from Messenian Abia

Ἀριστόδαμος VI\V BC

Poralla 124; Herodotus VII 229-231, IX 71

He was the only survivor of Thermopylae in 480. He tried to cleanse

this stain from his honor by a hero’s death at Plataea in 479.

Ἀριστόδαμος V\IV BC

Poralla 125; Xenophon Hellenica IV 2.9-23; Pausanias III 5.7

Collateral member of the house of the Agids

As regent for Agesipolis he led the army and won a victory at Nemea in 394.

Ἀριστόδαμος V\IV BC

Poralla 126; Plutarch Moralia (narrationes amatoriae 3) 773b-774d (cf. Xeno­phon Hellenica V 4.56/7)

Harmost in Oreus

According to the story in Plutarch he. must have been harmost before the battle at Leuctra. In this period a harmost could have been in Oreus only after the fall of Athens and before the sack of Oreus in 377/6 by Alketas.

Ἀριστόδαμος (1) I BC

IG V 1. 124a, 212b

Agoranomos in the year of [Pa]us[a]nias (3)a; member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of Aristomachos (3)b

Ἀριστοκλῆς (16)

Ἀριστοκλῆ[ς] (17) ὁ καὶ Ζῆθος ROMAN PERIOD

IG V 1. 746 (ὁ καὶ Ζῆθος seems to be in another hand)

Gravemarker with a relief of a man, seated in a chair, holding a drinking

vessel in his right hand above which a serpent can be seen

against the Athenians.

Μ(ᾶρκος) Αὐρήλιος Ἀριστοκράτης (8) II\III AD

Rizakis 96; IG V 1. 529a, 530b, 653Ac

Son of Damainetos (5)abc

Priest by descentab, “best in every way”b; “the forty-eighth descendant of Heracles, forty-fourth of the Dioscuri”ab; gymnasiarch for life with

Dionysios (2) and Aristoteles (4)a; “reproachless” citizen and gymnasiarcha

M. Aurelius Euarestos was synephebe with him and Ti. Claudius Eiranion (1)c

Paid for a memorial to M. Aur(elius) Pankratidas (1)b

Ἀριστοκράτης (23) = (12?) I-II AD

Grunauer, p. 53 (emission mark 22 ), Gruppe XVI (43-31 BC), Serie 17, Tafel 12, Gruppe XVII (43-31 BC), Serie 12, Tafel 13, Gruppe XXI (35-31 BC), Serie 1, Tafel 17 associated on a coin with Damares (6a); Grunauer, p. 53 (emission mark 23 ), Gruppe XVII (43-31 BC), Serie 13, Tafel 13, Aristokrates only: Gruppe XXI (35-31 BC), Serie 2, Tafel 17 associated on a coin with Timaristos

Name on a coin—perhaps the mint official but more likely the holder of

an office, gerousias, ephor, or eponymous patronomos

Ἀριστοκρατίδας (1) MID I BC

IG V 1. 141, 211

Eponymous patronomos

Ἀρισ[το]κρατίδας (2) I BC

IG V 1. 209

Father of Damokrates (3)

Ἀριστοκρατίδας (3) I AD

SEG XI 511

Father of Nikias (1)

[Ἀριστ]οκρατίδας, IG V 1. 655, error for [Δαμ]οκρατίδας (3)
Ἀριστόκριτος V BC

Poralla 129; Plutarch Lysander 2; IG II2 1388 line 32, 1400 line 15; Pausanias VI 3.14; Xenophon Hellenica II 4.28; Diodorus XIV 13.5/6

Father of Lysander and Libys.

He belonged to a branch of the Heraclid line but not a line leading to the throne. His family was also closely tied to the royal house of Cyrene.

Ἀριστομένης (7) I BC

Father of Aristomenes (1)

([Ἀρ]ιστομένης [8]) I\II AD

IG V 1. 103

Father of [Ar]istomenes (2)

Ἀριστομενίδας V\IV BC

Poralla 134; Pausanias III 9.3

Belonged to the Spartan court of five men who sentenced the Plataeans to death in 427. In 396 he was sent as ambassador to Thebes.

Pausanias says that he was the father of the mother of Agesilaos, which is totally impossible (because of the dates). He may have been the father-in-law of Agesilaos, that is the father of Kleora. Or the name of the father of the mother of Agesilaus may have been Aristomenidas, but a different person. See Μελησιππίδας.

Ἀριστομενίδας (1a) EARLY II AD

IG V 1. 102 (Ἀριστομενούδας, cf. SEG XI 579)a; SEG XI 544b

Son of Kleomachos (4)b

Nomophylax in the year of [C.] Julius Antipatros (1)b, AD 113/4 or 114/5

[Gerousias] for the second time in the year of Ti. Claudius

Aris[toboulos] (1)a, AD 129/30

Son of Nikephoros (20)[a]b

{Grandson of Aristoneikidas (3)}

[Spondoph(oros) in the year of Meniskos (1)]a, AD 135/6 (and thus no

older than about twenty, born ca. 110-115?)

Julius Nikandros (3)b, AD 161-169

Ἀριστόπολις I BC

IG V 1. 209 (or is aristopolis a title?)

Son of Damocharis (4)

Ἄριστος END V BC

Poralla 135; Diodorus XIV 10, 70.3 (Ἀρέτης)

A Spartiate, who was sent to Syracuse in 404 to reinforce the army of Dionysius (Given the difficulty Diodorus has with the name he may be the same as the Aristoteles <Poralla 137> below—E. Cavaignac, Revue Critique LXXVII <1914>, i, 2-4 <review>)

Ἀριστοτέλης AFTER 404/3 BC

Poralla 136; IG V 1. 1230

Witness from a dedicatory inscription of Ekephylos from Taenarum, time

of the ephor Ariston (after 404/3)

Ἀριστοτέλης V\IV BC

Poralla 137; Diodorus XIV 78.1

He was a leader of mercenaries with Dionysius of Syracuse. Because of his ambiguous attitude towards Dionysius he was arrested in 396 and sent to Sparta for judgement.

Αὐρήλιος Ἀριστοτέλης (1) II\III AD

Rizakis 99 (appendix, stemma iii); IG V 1. 601a, 1240b

Son of Hellanikos (1)ab

Husband of Aur(elia) Aristokleiaa

Father of Aur(elia) Charteris (2)a

Father-in-law of Aur(elius) Kleandros (3) ho kai Meniosa

Ephor between AD 213 and 217b

[Κλα]ύ(διος) Ἀριστοτέλης (2) II AD

Rizakis 266; IG V 1. 836

Son of [Kal]likrates (48)?

—? (compare with Aristoteles <3> and in particular 109)

Πομ(πήιος?) [Ἀρ]ιστοτέλης (3) END II AD

Son of Menopha[ne]s

[N]eikephoros (12) was his synephebe in the year of Cl(audius)

[Ab]askantos (1)

Τιβ(έριος) Κλαύδιος Ἀριστοτέλης (4) MID-LATE II AD

Rizakis 263 (“three individuals”), 264 (Stemmata I & VII), 265, 267; IG V

1. 68a, 109b, 527c, 528d, 529e, 547f, 591g, 592h; SEG XI 493i, 528j, 550k, 839l

Son of Spartiatikos (8)cg

Husband of Julia Etymokledeia (1)g

Father of Claudia Philokratia (2)g and Clau(dia) Longina (1)fh

Grandfather (through Longina) of Mem(mia) Longina (2) and P. Mem(mius) Damare[s] (4)f

Spondophoro[s in the year of Eudamos (6)]k, AD 139/40-42

Philocaesarbd, most justb, patriot, aristopoliteutes for life, “descended from Poseidon”d, axiologotatos, boagos, paid for a memorial to M. Aur(elius) Aphrodisios (3)c, gymnasiarch with Dionysios (2)e for lifed; presbys of gerontes in the year of Timomenes (1)b, ca. AD 142-145/6; official of gamesl; ephor in the year of Biadasj, AD 153/4; eponymous patronomosai, ca. AD 143-146/7

(Are these two individuals conflated?)

Ἀριστοτέλης (5) I BC\I AD

(Δέκμος) Κασκέλλιος Ἀριστοτέλης (6) II AD

Rizakis 214; IG V 1. 39, 69, 70, 71; SEG XI 526, 554

Eponymous patronomos, AD 158/9-60

(Not a native Lacedaemonian but of Cyrene)

The following Aristoteles are likely to be one of the prominent bearers of that name.

Ἀριστοφάνης (2) MID IV AD

Libanius epistulae 1214 (AD 364)

Ἀρίστων MID VI BC

Poralla 138; Herodotus I 67, VI 61-63; Pausanias III 7.7-8; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s.v.) 218ab

King from the house of the Eurypontids

Son of Agasikles

Because his first two marriages were childless, he married a third time ... the wife of his friend Agetos. From this marriage came the later king Damaratos. Ariston was a contemporary of Croesus and Anaxandridas. While he was king the long war against Tegea was ended.

Ἀρίστων VI BC

Poralla 139; Pausanias V 23.7

Brother of Telestas

An artist (bronze worker)

From Sparta

Ἀρίστων MID V BC

Olymp 303; P. Oxy 222

Ethnic A—, Λ—, or M—

Boxer in the boys’ class, Ol 85 = 488 BC

Γάιος Ἰούλιος Ἀρίων (9) MID II AD

SEG XI 501

Aristindes; syndikos epi ta ethe; ambassador to Rome, paying his own expenses “to the throne of the emperor and to C. Maximus;” synthetes to Neapolis, not accepting travel expenses; Panhellen, gerousias, ephor during the disturbances (ἐπὶ τῶν νεωτερισμῶν), gerousias again, tamias in the year of Sokrates (5), after AD 168

[Α]ὐρ(ήλιος) Ἀρκαδίων (ΙΙ) (Ἀρκαδίωνος) II/III AD

Catalogue of magistrates

Ἀρκαδίων MID I BC

Grunauer, p. 53 (emission mark 11 ), Gruppe XIV (48-40 BC), Serie 16, Tafel 8, Gruppe XV (48-40 BC), Serie 18, Tafel 10, Gruppe XVI (43-31 BC), Serie 6, Tafel 11

Name on a coin—perhaps the mint official but more likely the holder of an office, gerousias, ephor, or eponymous patronomos

IG V 1. 1314

“Lakon ho[m]oios”

A pai(anias) in the year of Me(mmius) Damares (5) and a worshipper

of Damoea-in-Thalamae

Ἀρκεσίλαος MID V BC

Poralla 141; Thucydides VIII 39; Olymp 305, 311

Father of the Spartiate Lichas

He won twice at Olympia (448-444?) with the four horse chariot and

had a portrait there because of the victory

Ἀρκεσίλαος (1) MID III BC

Plutarch Agis 18.7

One of the three friends of king Agis IV who visited him in his asylum and once formed an escort for him (so he could leave his place of asylum and bathe)

Ἀρκεσίλαος (2) DIED 184 BC

Polybius XXIII 6.1-2

In 184 BC he accompanied Agesipolis (2) on a journey to Rome as envoy for a group of exiles and was killed by pirates

(Might he be the grandson of “1”?)

Ἀρκεσί[λαος] (3) EARLY III BC

SEG XI 412

Father of Polyphantos, a [La]cedaemonian

Ἄρκεσος, Poralla 141a; Plutarch Moralia (de genio Socratis) 598f, cf.

Ἄρκισσος

Ἄρκισσος V\IV BC

Poralla 142; Plutarch Moralia (de genio Socratis 34) 598f; Pelopidas 12-13

One of the three harmosts who in the year 379 gave up the Cadmeia prematurely. He was executed in Corinth for that. (Though not stated specifically he is certainly a Spartiate as his two colleagues were.)

IG IX2 137B

Father of Archippos (2), a [Lace]daemonian

IV 2.3d

Son of Nabisad

He was sent to Rome as a hostage, ca. 195 BC,abcd where he died.b

Τιβέριος Κλαύδιος Ἁρμόνικος (2a = 5) I AD

Rizakis 296-299 q.v.; IG V 1. [20b, (cf. SEG XI 565: Τιβ(έριος) Κλα(ύδιος) Ἁ[ρμ]ό[νεικος])a, 79b, 97 (SEG XI 564)c, 169 (SEG XI 632)d, 275e, 480f; SEG XI 546g, 563h

Son of Pratonikos (28)a

Father of (Ti. Claudius) Pleistoxenos (1 = 2)a and Ti. Claudius Xeno­phanes (1)ab

{Grandfather of Ti. Claudius Harmonikos (2b)}

A member of the Cynosurian obef

Honored by his obe and by the city in the year of C. Julius Lakon (3) for his generosity as gymnasiarchf

Deputy patronomos to Sikleidas (2)e

Name in a catalogued

Gerousias (for the first time)h

(His sons were sysseitoi in the year of Kleandros <5>, AD 99/100, which may indicate that he held an office in that year, but not ephor, nomophylax, or bideos, which are known <SEG XI 512, 539 {IG V 1. 79}, 609>)b

Gerousias for the second time in the year of C. Julius Philoklidas (3)c, AD 91/2-95/6 or earlier

Gerousias for the third time [in the year of Menekles]a, AD 96/7

Τιβ(έριος) Κλαύδιος Ἁρμόνικος (2b) EARLY II AD

IG V 1. 485a; ZPE XLI (1981) 171b

Son of (Ti. Claudius) Pleistoxenos (1 = 2)

Brother of Ti. Claudius Xenophanes (1)

Grandson of Ti. Claudius Harmoneikos (2a), hence a member of the Cyno­surian obe

“Took the honors of the aristopoliteia according to the law and from the demos exactly as the godlike emperor Caesar Trajan Hadrian Augustus and Aemilius Juncus the dikaiodotes wrote concerning him.”a

(Aemilius Juncus was the legatus propraetore in Achaea, AD 128/9, cf.

IG II/III2 4210, see also Rizakis 20, AD 127-137.)

Gerousiasb

Ἀρχελαίδας V\IV BC

Poralla 146; Hellenica Oxyrhynchia 9.2, fr. 20,11?

The name is secure. The circumstances suggest that he is a Lacedaemonian. That he is a nauarch (of the year 397/6) and predecessor of Pollis is a conjecture: Πόλλις] ναύαρχος ἐκ Λακε[δαίμονος εἰς τὴ]n Ἀρχελαίδα κατα[στὰς διάδοξος].

Ἀρχελάεις CHRISTIAN ERA

IG V 1. 822

“Slave of God”

Gravemarker with an entreaty that there be no desecration of the tomb

Ἀρχέλαος IX BC

Poralla 147; Herodotus VII 204, Pausanias III 2.5-6, Eusebius I 225

Agid king

Son of Agesilaos I

Father of Teleklos

He was supposed to have taken the city of Aigys

Ancient chronographers give him a reign of 60 years, 885/4-826/5, and

make him a contemporary of Charillos

Ἀρχέμβροτος VII BC

Poralla 148; Suidas s. v. Τυρταῖος

Father of Tyrtaeus

Ἀρχίας

Poralla 149; IG V 1. 1134

Name on an early inscription found in Geraki

Ἀρχίας MID VI BC

Poralla 150; Herodotus III 55; Plutarch Moralia (de Herodoti malignitate 22) 860c

Father of Samios

A Spartiate from Pitane, fell around 525 in the battle against Polykrates before Samos

Ἀρχίας MID V BC

Poralla 151; Herodotus III 55

Son of Samios

Contemporary of Herodotus; he is probably the father of the nauarch Samios, whom Sparta sent to help Cyrus the Younger in 401

Ἀρχιδάμεια VII BC

Poralla 152; Pausanias IV 17.1

Priestess of Demeter in Laconian Aigila; she was supposed to have freed

the imprisoned Aristomenes in the Second Messenian War

Ἀρχιδάμια DIED 241 BC

Plutarch Agis 4.1a, 20.3b, Pyrrhus 27.4-5c; Polyaenus VIII 49d

Daughter of King “Kleadas” = Kleomenes II?d

Wife of Eudamidas {(1) I?}

Mother of Agesistrata, Agesilaos (2), {and Archidamos (2) IV?}b

Grandmother of Agis (1) IV, Archidamos (3) <V>, and Hippomedon (1)a <Polybius (IV 35.13) states that Hippomedon was in the line of Eurypontid succession, which would be readily understandable if he were the grandson of a king. Agesilaos, his father, was the son of a Eudamidas. Eudamidas I was a Eurypontid. It seems likely then that Archidamia was the wife of Eudamidas I.>

During the invasion of Laconia by Pyrrhus, 272 BC, Archidamia opposed a plan to send the women and children of Sparta to Crete. She organized the women to fortify the city, carry weapons, and treat the wounded. She aided and encouraged the Spartan soldiers.c

She was one of the wealthiest women in Sparta, but she supported the reforms of Agis IV with both her money and her influence.a

She was executed after his fall in 241 BCb

Ἀρχιδαμίδας IV\III BC?

Poralla 153; Plutarch Moralia (apophthegmata Laconica s. v.) 218b; Lycurgus 20

A Spartiate contemporary of Hecataeus (of Abdera?)—he responded to a criticism of Hecataeus and to a question about the number of Spartiates

Ἀρχίδαμος I

Poralla 154; Herodotus VIII 131

King from the Eurypontid house

Son of Anaxandridas

Father of Anaxilas

Ἀρχίδαμος

Poralla 155; Pausanias III 7.5

According to the false kings’ list of Pausanias he was a king from the Eurypontid house, son of Theopompos and father of Zeuxidamos. He is supposed to have died before his father. Perhaps to be identified with Archidamos (Poralla 154).

Ἀρχίδαμος

Poralla 156; Pausanias III 7.6

According to the false kings’ list of Pausanias he was a king from the Eurypontid house and son of Anaxidamos and father of Agasikles

Ἀρχίδαμος II MID V BC

Poralla 157; Plutarch Agesilaus 1a, 2.6; Herodotus VI 71b; Xenophon Agesilaus 9.6c, Hellenica V 2.3d; Pausanias III 7.10e, 15.1f, VI 1.6g; Diodorus XI 63.4-64.1h, XII 42.6-8i, 47.1-2j; Thucydides II 10-12k, 18-23l, 47m, 71-78n, III 1o; Libanius declamationes 20.19; Athenaeus XIII 566a

King from the house of the Eurypontids

Son of Zeuxidamos

Father of Agis II (from his first marriage with his step-aunt Lampido)ab and Agesilaos II and Kyniska (by his second wife Eupolia)acfg

When shortly before 476 Leotychidas had to go into exile at Tegea, his grandson Archidamos assumed the rulee. Whether he had already taken part in the battles of Tegea in 473 and Dipaia can not be known. He was first mentioned in the great earthquake in Sparta in 464, where he saved the state through his presence of mindh. He distinguished himself in the ensuing battles against the Messeniansd.

Archidamos commanded the first invasion of Attica in the year 431 and 430klm. In 429 he took Plataea and in the next year led an army into Attica for the third time.no

He became sick and died at the latest in the Winter 427/6.

Ἀρχίδαμος III DIED 338 BC

Poralla 158; SEG XI 457 (treaty with [Ach]aeans); Xenophon Hellenica V 4.25a, VI 4.18-19b, 26c, VII 1.28-32d, 4.20-25e, 5.12-13f; Plutarch Agis 3g, Agesilaus 19h, 33i, 34j, 40k; Camillus 19.8l; Pausanias III 10.3-5m, VI 4.9n; Arrian Anabasis II 13.6o; Isocrates Epistulae IX (Archidamos)p; Diodorus XVI 24q, 39r, 59s, 62-63, 88u; Aeschines II 133v; Athenaeus VII 289e, XII 536cd, XIII 591bw; Libanius orationes 64.83; declamationes (Archidami defensio) XXIV passim

King from the house of the Eurypontids (born about 400)

Son of Agesilaos II and Kleora.

Brother of Eupolia and Prolytaah

Husband of Deinicha

Father of Agis III, Eudamidas I and Agesilaosgmo

In 371 he led the defeated army of Kleombrotos back from Megara to Sparta. (Diodorus XV 54-55 in error puts Archidamos also at the battle of Leuctra.)bc

In the years 367 and 364 Archidamos campaigned against the Arcadians in the fielddei.

Isokrates put a speech in his mouth that he was supposed to have delivered at the Peace Congress in Sparta in 366/5p.

In 362 he was occupied in the defense of Sparta against the Thebansfj.

After the death of Agesilaos II in the winter of 360/59 he ascended the thronek.

At the outbreak of the Sacred War Archidamos in secret helped the Phociansmq. Around 352 he fought against Megalopolisr, and in 346 led an army to help Phocis, but because of the ambiguities of the situation among the Phocian leaders returned to Sparta with nothing accomplishedsv.

After that he was sent to Italy to help Tarentum in a war against the Lucanians. He sailed first to Crete where he refounded Lyttos. In Italy he fought a battle at Mandonion 338—on the seventh of the month Metageitnionl—lost the battle and his lifegmtuv.

He had a portrait bust in Olympian and a statue in Delphiw.

Ἀρχίδαμος (1) I BC

IG V 1. 210

Son of Agathok[le]s (30)

{Brother of [Ch]airon (1)?}

Member of the cult of Poseidon of Taenarum in the year of

Kallikrates (33)

Ἀρχίδαμος (2) IV DIED 294 BC?

Plutarch Agis 3.3a; Demetrius 35.1b; [Polyaenus IV 7.9-10]c; [Pausanias II 8.5; III 10.5; VII 7.3; VIII 8.11, 10.5-8, 27.13-14, 36.6 confuses Archidamos and Agis (1) IV and perhaps other kings]

Son of Eudamidas (1) I {and Archidamia}a

{Brother of Agesistrata and Agesilaos (2)}

Father of Eudamidas (2) IIa

{Grandfather of Agis IV, Archidamos (3) <V>, and Hippomedon (1)}

Eurypontid king

He fought a battle with Demetrius near Mantinea, where he was defeated, 294 BCbc There is no further mention of Archidamos in the sources and he may have been killed in this battle.

Ἀρχίδαμος (3) {V} DIED 227 BC

Polybius IV 35.13a; V 37.1-5b; VIII 35.3-5c; Plutarch Cleomenes 1.1d; 5.2-4e; comparatio Agis Cleomenes Ti. Gracchus C. Gracchus 5.2f

Son of Eudamidas (2) II and Agesistrata

Brother of Agis (1) IVe

First cousin and son-in-law of Hippomedon (1)a

Father of two sons, names unknowna

Upon the execution of his brother he fled into exile in Messene and lived there until he was persuaded by Kleomenes (1) III to return and become the Eurypontid kingbdef. When he returned, he was murderedbcef.

Whether he actually became king is unclear.

Ἄρχιον

IG XII 9. 794

Lakaina

Gravemarker in Eretria

J. Baillet, Inscriptions grecques et latines des tombeaux des rois ou Syringes à Thébes (Memoires de l’institut Fr. d’Archéol. Orientale, 42, 1920-26), 216
